sub_title: Chairman at Differential Satellite Navigation Systems '93
summary: Serving as chairman and (vice-)president of the board of several (inter)national organisations Rein van Gooswilligen MSc, MBA, MMar, FRIN continued a sea-going career  (Masters License - Ocean Going). He served twelve years as president of the Dutch Pilots’ Corporation. Rein is immediate past president of the Netherlands Institute of Navigation (NIN),  past chairman of the Council of the European Group of Institutes of Navigation (EUGIN), and vice-president of the International Association of Institutes of Navigation.  He has a Master of Science degree (Management) from Nyenrode University (Netherlands) and a Master of Business Administration degree from Rochester University, Rochester New York, U.S.A. He served as member of the Advisory Board of the International Maritime Pilots’ Association (IMPA) and the Council of presidents of the European Maritime Pilots’ Association (EMPA). Capt. Rein van Gooswilligen is Knight of the Order of Orange-Nassau, Fellow of the Royal Institute of Navigation and Honorary Member of a number of (inter)national organisations.

school.name: University of Rochester - Simon Business School

profile_positions.description: Differential Satellite Navigation Systems was founded in the early 90's to establish contact between professionals, scientists, industrial representatives and members of the navigation community. The organisation has been instrumental in organizing several international navigation conferences.
profile_positions.title: Chairman

profile_positions.description: The mission of the Netherlands Institute of Navigation is to promote, develop broaden and spread the knowledge of navigation in the broadest sense of the word. NIN does this through stimulation of research into navigation in co-operation with research institutes, educational/teaching institutes, professional groups, government and industry. NIN’s activities encompass land, sea, air and space related subjects. On a regular basis meetings, seminars and symposia are organised in which one or more navigation subjects are presented and/or discussed. NIN is a member of the European Group of Institutes of Navigation (EUGIN) and the International Association of Institutes of Navigation (IAIN). NIN participates in the European Journal of Navigation.
profile_positions.title: Member Advisory Board

company.name: International Association of Institutes of Navigation

profile_positions.company: International Association of Institutes of Navigation
profile_positions.title: Member Officers Committee

profile_positions.company: International Association of Institutes of Navigation
profile_positions.description:
As a specialized agency of the United Nations, IMO is the global standard-setting authority for the safety, security and environmental performance of international shipping. Its main role is to create a regulatory framework for the shipping industry that is fair and effective, universally adopted and universally implemented.

The International Association of Institutes of Navigation's (IAIN) object is to unite national and multinational institutes and organisations which aim to foster human activities at sea, in the air, in space and on land, and who many benefit from the development of the science and practise of navigation and related information techniques. 

Early in 1975, the Presidents of the Institutes of Navigation of Australia, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States agreed to the formal declaration of an International Association of Institutes of Navigation (IAIN). The first General Assembly was held in London and the first constitution was adopted on 15 October 1975. In 1976, IAIN was granted consultative status to the International Maritime Organisation (IMO). Since then many proposals and technical papers on different subjects have been put forward to IMO on such matters as traffic separation, collision regulations and accuracy standards for navigation.
profile_positions.title: International Maritime Organisation representative

NIN does this through stimulation of research into navigation in co-operation with research institutes, educational/teaching institutes, professional groups, government and industry. On a regular basis meetings, seminars and symposia are organised in which one or more navigation subjects are presented and/or discussed. company.name: European Group of Institutes of Navigation

profile_positions.company: European Group of Institutes of Navigation
profile_positions.description: In the mid-1990s, the Institutes of Navigation of several European States decided to work together with a view to advising European institutions in the fields of navigation and related issues. The word ‘navigation’ embraced all modes of position location in air, on land, at sea and in space.  Originally established by the Institutes of France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, the Nordic countries and the United Kingdom, EUGIN has since then welcomed the newly created Institutes of Austria, Poland, Portugal, Spain and Switzerland, the Swedish Radio Navigation Board and honorary members, Galileo Services and Unmanned Vehicle Systems International.
profile_positions.title: Chairman, Council

profile_positions.description:
Nyenrode Business Universiteit is an enterprise in itself. Universiteit Nyenrode B.V. is an independent business whose equity is 100 percent owned by Stichting Nyenrode (the Nyenrode Foundation). The University’s Executive Board is therefore accountable to the Board of the Nyenrode Foundation.

In addition to owning the equity of Universiteit Nyenrode, the Nyenrode Foundation is responsible for Landgoed Nijenrode (the Nyenrode Estate). The Board of the Foundation is accountable to the Foundation’s Supervisory Board
profile_positions.title: Member of the Supervisory Board

company.name: VCV, Nyenrode Business University alumni association

profile_positions.company: VCV, Nyenrode Business University alumni association
profile_positions.description:
In 1951 the Voortgezette Compagnie van Verre (VCV) was formed to serve Nyenrode University´s alumni community. The VCV at present represents approximately 5000 alumni from amongst others Nyenrode’s NOIB, BBA, IDP, IMBA, RNEMBA, PDP and MSc programmes. Approximately 20% of the alumni live abroad. VCV members form part of the worldwide network of Nyenrodians. VCV’s objectives are:
•	To build and expand a strong network of Nyenrodians 
•	To offer it’s members added value activities, both in a social and professional context
•	To support Nyenrode University and the ‘Nieuwe Compagnie van Verre’
The VCV organises a number of activities in order to maintain and further develop its network. These include amongst others publication of the VCV Magazine, circle activities, a benefits program, publication of an address book, an active website, access to online VCV database, social, professional and educational activities and the VCV Career Centre for job-future and other work-related issues.
profile_positions.title: Vice President

profile_positions.description: Safeway Maritime Rotterdam BV is a joint venture between STODEL (50 percent) - the Dutch Pilotage Organization training and education department - and the Shipping & Transport College (50 percent). Both partners offer their expertise and position nationally as well as internationally within the joint venture for the joint service of education, courses and training, including i.a. promotion, marketing, recruitment, organizational support, internal support as well as providing professional teachers, instructors, simulators, educational and training vessels, training supported by computers, practical works, educational subjects and educational media.
profile_positions.title: Chairman/Member of the Supervisory Board

profile_positions.description:
Loodswezen is organized both on a professional and on a bussiness level. All registered pilots are professionally organized in a public body for the profession: Nederlandse Loodsencorporatie [NLC]. In addition to it's legal tasks the NLC’s main objective is to maintain and improve the quality of job performance. About 425 independent registered pilots handle 90.000 shipping movements annually. The present-day registered pilot is an independent professional and acts as advisor to the master. With the master’s permission, he is in charge of navigation on board a ship contributing considerably to the safe and efficient handling of nautical traffic and the protection of the marine environment and infrastructure. Pilots provide 24/7 service. 
The supporting company, Nederlands Loodswezen B.V. [NLBV] provides with approximately 400 employees general support to the pilots and their profession.
profile_positions.title: President

profile_positions.description: The International Maritime Pilots' Association, is primarily concerned with promoting professional standards of pilotage worldwide in the interests of pilots' safety. It seeks to fulfil this task by encouraging both consultation between its members and the exchange of technical information with other industry partners and regulators at the local, national and international levels.
profile_positions.title: Adviser Representative

company.name: The Netherlands Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals

volunteer_experiences.description: The organisation actively promotes animal welfare. The Board of Appeal hears appeals of those involved against decisions of the organisation and acts independetly of the board.

The Seafarer's Welfare's objectives are to support facilities for merchant seafarers in the Port of Rotterdam and its environment irrespective of nationality, religion or ethnic background and strives to ensure that all welfare needs are met through the most effective deployment of resources. It facilitates the work of those working in the sector through the provision of grants and support services. The organisation holds liaison with other organisations in the field and participates where possible in the Port Welfare Committee to further and develop local welfare services.
